subject: RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy
msgSnippet: ...  ... A quick question: how do you have test dependency (in your sense) without test content dependency? When I wrote a few examples, I found that
messageBody:
>So said Adam Jack on 2003-07-30 --------------------
>David wrote:
>
<snip />
>I think test content dependency is wrong, but not what I am saying.

A quick question: how do you have test dependency (in your sense) without test content dependency?

When I wrote a few examples, I found that when one test depends on another (in your sense) there is duplication in the tests. At a minimum, the two tests make the same assertions.

>Either
>that, or you decouple yourself from everything you do, a purist goal of no
>real world value. Code used code, that is a dependency.

You can have interface dependency without implementation dependency. That is the decoupling mechanism that tends to eliminate your test dependency issue.

<snip />
>This is all about test content dependency -- side effects -- and I never
>meant that. Why get a fruit basket full of errors when fruit is bad? I was
>actually trying to reduce this mess of an output to "the *possible* root
>cause -- and if nothing else, a place to start cleaning up".

The closer an object is to the core of your application, the more important (I think) that failures in that object yell loudly and annoyingly. If your project has a big problem with core classes failing on a regular basis, then maybe you have a process/people problem, as opposed to a technical problem.

And lest you think I'm just deflecting, I'm not; I am sincerely trying to balance providing you a solution with protecting the integrity of the core of JUnit.

Take care.
